Prompt:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
Answer: There is no easy answer when it comes to overcoming feelings of worthlessness, but it is possible. First, it is important to understand that these feelings are often based on irrational thoughts. If you can identify the thoughts that are contributing to your feelings of worthlessness, you can start to challenge and reframe them. Second, make an effort to do things that make you feel good about yourself. This could involve engaging in activities that make you feel accomplished, spending time with people who make you feel loved and valued, or simply taking care of yourself in small ways. Lastly, be patient with yourself. These feelings likely did not develop overnight and they will not go away overnight either. Allow yourself time and space to work through them at your own pace.

Prompt: I self-harm, and I stop for awhile. Then when I see something sad or depressing, I automatically want to self-harm.

If you find that you're self-harming when you see something sad or depressing, it might be a sign that you're not dealing with your emotions in a healthy way. Prompt: How do therapists classify the type of personality their clients have? What characteristics do they look at to decide what type of personality the client has? I've read about this online, but I'd like to understand this from a therapist's point of view.
Answer: There is no one answer to this question, as different therapists may use different methods to classify the personality types of their clients. However, some common methods used to assess personality include administering personality tests, observing client behavior, and interviewing the client. therapists may also look at characteristics such as the client's level of introversion or extroversion, their ability to cope with stress, and any patterns of thought or behavior that seem to be recurrent.

Prompt: How can I get to a place where I can be content from day to day?

However, some tips that may help include staying present and mindful of the moment, practicing gratitude, and connecting with loved ones. Additionally, it can be helpful to focus on activities that bring joy and meaning into your life, and to let go of negative thoughts and emotions that do not serve you.

Prompt:

Prompt: I struggle with depression as well as pretty intense mood swings throughout the month. I experience highs where I feel amazing and energetic and then lows where I lack focus, energy, and generally have a more dark outlook on my life. How can I live a more balanced life?

• Identifying and avoid triggers that can cause mood swings or make depression worse.

• Talking to a therapist or counselor who can help you understand your emotions and develop healthy coping mechanisms.

• Taking medication as prescribed by a doctor, if necessary.

Prompt: I self-harm, and I stop for awhile. Then when I see something sad or depressing, I automatically want to self-harm.
Answer: There are a few things that you can do to try and break the cycle of self-harming when you see something sad or depressing. Prompt: I have been diagnosed with general anxiety and depression by my family doctor. They wrote a prescription for me to have an emotional support dog, I have the paper work, and I gave it to my apartment manager. They said I can't keep the ESD because I'm not disabled. What do you suggest I do?

Prompt: Every winter I find myself getting sad because of the weather. How can I fight this?
Answer:
There are a few things you can do to try and fight the winter blues:

1. Get outside: Even though it may be cold, getting some fresh air can do wonders for your mood. bundle up and take a walk, go for a run, or just sit outside for a few minutes each day.

2. Exercise: Exercise releases endorphins, which have mood-boosting effects. So, even if you don’t love working out, it can still help you feel better during the winter.

3. Connect with friends and family: Spending time with loved ones can help chase away the blues. Whether you meet up in person or just stay in touch via text, calls, or social media, staying connected can help you feel less alone and more supported.

4. Do something you enjoy: Make time for activities that make you happy. This could be reading, playing music, watching your favorite TV show, or anything else that brings you joy.

5. Seek professional help: If you’re struggling to manage your winter blues, it may be time to seek professional help. A therapist can help you understand and manage your symptoms, and they can provide additional support and resources.

Prompt: I'm unemployed just relocated. I can't get approved for a place to live because of past mistakes which follow me to this day. Second, try to negotiate with the landlord. Explain your situation and why you believe you will be a good tenant. Offer to pay a higher deposit or agree to a shorter lease.

Third, try to find housing that is not as competitive. There may be less demand for housing in certain areas, which can make it easier to get approved.

Finally, keep trying. It may take a few tries to find a landlord who is willing to work with you, but it is possible to find housing even with a past eviction on your record.

- Having a mental health condition that makes it difficult to interact with others or cope with anxiety
- Having a low self-esteem or feeling like you are not good enough to socialize with others
- Feeling like you do not fit in with others or feeling like you are not interesting enough to be worth socializing with

If you are struggling with anxiety and social isolation, it is important to seek out professional help in order to address the underlying causes of your symptoms. Therapy can be an extremely effective treatment for anxiety and social isolation, and can help you to understand and manage your symptoms in a more holistic way.

Prompt: I'm socially awkward. I've always want to be popular. I've had the opportunity to be popular, but every time I get i,t I'm too scared. All I have to do is talk the popular people. They're really nice to me, but I'm too scared of change. I really want to work up the courage to lose my fear.

Prompt: For the last year, my adolescent son and daughter have been driving me nuts with fighting. I'm at my wits end. How can I get them to stop and get along?
Answer:
There is no single answer to this question, as the best way to stop fighting between siblings will vary depending on the individual children and the specific situation. However, some tips to help reduce fighting between siblings include:

Encouraging communication and problem-solving: Help your children learn to communicate with each other and to problem-solve disagreements. This can involve modeling good communication skills yourself, and helping them practice communicating with each other in a calm and respectful way.

Encouraging positive reinforcement: Try to focus on catching your children being good to each other, and reinforcing that behaviour with praise and rewards. This can help to encourage more positive behaviour and reduce fighting.

Setting clear rules and consequences: Make sure your children know what behaviour is expected of them, and what the consequences will be if they fight. This may include things like time-outs or loss of privileges.

Making sure they have enough attention: Sometimes fighting between siblings can be a sign that they are seeking attention. Make sure to spend quality time with each child individually, and give them plenty of positive attention.

Prompt: My boyfriend and I have been together for five years now. Throughout the entire first day that we met, he and I had the opportunity to interact quite a lot and instantly sparked a deep connection with one another. On the third night, my mother finally caught us, and I was kicked out of my house. I left with him of course, and we went from meeting each other to being like a married couple. It was very hard for us. His stepdad also kicked him out of his home, and we were staying at cheap hotels and friend's houses with the little money we had. I quit my job and dropped out of school because it was hard to do anything without a stable home. There were times when we had nowhere else to go but sleep in the car outside a Walmart parking lot. Our honeymoon stage, as they call it, probably only lasted one month. After that, it was a downward spiral. We were constantly arguing about money, food, and our families. We kept having the famous "you're doing it wrong—do it this way" argument. After six months, we moved across the country only to live the same thing, and that's when the violence started. One afternoon, after a serious argument, he got into his truck and threatened to leave me. I was frightened that he would actually go through with his word, given that we had just moved to a place where we knew no one. He told me to let him leave or he would hit me. He had once promised he would never touch me, so I challenged him to do it. He slapped me, and ever since that time, when we have serious fights, he loses control and hurts me.
